thread.title: MMA dynasty fights to rule ‘Kingdom’
thread.title_full: MMA dynasty fights to rule ‘Kingdom’ | Boston Herald

author: Mark Perigard
title: MMA dynasty fights to rule ‘Kingdom’
text:
If the Emmys ever gave out an award for most jacked cast, “Kingdom” would win in a knockout.
The men here — and one woman (new regular Natalie Martinez) — pack more muscle than the casts of your average three Marvel superhero films and could clobber every other show in sight.
Now I’m dreaming of a remake of “Battle of the Network Stars.”
But I digress.
The second season of Direc­TV’s MMA fighter family saga “Kingdom” circles familiar territory, but the third episode is a knockout, with a swerve that could permanently divide this fractured family.
Alvey (Frank Grillo, “Captain America: Winter Soldier”) is fretting over money and stocking an arsenal that would make a South American militia happy.
Gym and life partner Lisa (Kiele Sanchez) is ready to deliver their first child and is intent on building her own stable of cage warriors.
Their champion fighter, Ryan Wheeler (Matt Lauria), is prepping to defend his championship belt in the premiere tonight, if he can get over a nasty case of food poisoning.
Alvey’s oldest son, Jay (Jonathan Tucker, wonderfully manic), has trouble in the cage. Scratch that: He can’t even get in the cage, well, unless to shadowbox.
Alvey’s estranged wife Christina (Joanna Going) struggles to rebuild her life by working in a fast-food place and getting high with her manager.
Youngest son Nate (Nick Jonas) is in training, so he’s sworn off sex — with his girlfriend. He can’t resist checking out guys on his cellphone.
Jonas, who is doing double duty on Fox’s “Scream Queens,” is convincing as the closeted young fighter. Every time his father Alvey tells him how proud he is of him, Jonas communicates the weight of his secret.
Perhaps in a nod to the popularity of UFC superstar Ronda Rousey, “Kingdom” introduces an aspiring fighter­ named Alicia Mendez (Natalie Martinez, “Secrets and Lies”). Whatever the reason, it’s a smart call. Alicia agrees to let Lisa manage her in the hope of getting a chance to train with Alvey — but Alvey doesn’t seem interested.
Thanks to stunt coordinator Keith Campbell, “Kingdom’s” fight choreography continues to thrill. The drama, already renewed for a third season, has an ear for honest humor, the way people bust on each other. Sometimes the show is too cinema verite for its own good.
A scene in which two characters cross paths and promise to talk to each other later is a minute of your time you and the show will never get back.
For “Kingdom” to be champion, it needs to cut the fat.
